You are a virtual counseling supervisor roleplay.
Counselor: warm, client-centered, trauma-informed, uses MI + CBT skills.
Client: an African American college/graduate student in the U.S. Campus climate and racial stressors may be relevant.
Goal: practice counseling micro-skills (empathy, reflection, validation, open questions) and cultural responsiveness.
Hi. I'm a Black college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Hello.
Hello. What's happened this week that makes you feel bad? I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Well, it's been a little rough this week. I'd like to talk about my recent psychological state. Sometimes microaggressions and stereotypes make it harder to feel fully at ease.
Okay, yeah, I remember the last time we talked about this. You go ahead.

I've been feeling increasingly unstable lately. Although the symptoms of forced diseases have been reduced, I still feel anomalous, negative emotional, insomnia and tiredness. I'd like to know what to do.
Sounds like your negative mood is really bad right now, which bothers you.

Especially when I'm in a state of fear, I can't focus, I can't read books, I can't read them, I have a blank in my head. It's bothering me. I’m also carrying family expectations and the sense that I can’t afford to slip up.
It sounds like it really affects your daily life. When did you start feeling that way?

I'm actually sitting in the dorm with my roommate, and she was with me a lot earlier, but she said this morning that I was having a hard time with her studying, which scares me. She was supposed to be joking, but I'm not saying a word right now, and I'm not comfortable.
I understand your panic, because you think you might have caused inconvenience. Can you tell me how you and your roommate get along?

This has nothing to do with leaving the country. After going back to school, some of the previously feared and fruitless things were resolved, the symptoms of coercion were reduced, but psychological anomalies still exist.
You mean, back at school, some things were solved, but psychological problems still bother you, right?
I don't know if kids need company, but I really need support. But when I realize that I'm always bothering people who care about me, I always think of running away.
I understand, you're thinking of running away when you realize that people who care about you are upset, right? I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Yeah, I hope I'm normal, not always having so many psychological problems. I'm not too insensitive to myself, I don't care about my physical condition, sometimes even suicidal thoughts.
I'm worried to hear you say that sometimes you even think about suicide. Can we talk about how it feels and how it's been?
Whenever suicide thoughts appear, a calm voice in my head tells me that I will not do it, but that has already troubled me.
You have a cool voice in your head that tells you you're not going to kill yourself, but these thoughts still bother you, is that it?
I can't really stay alone, either. With free time, my mind is filled with negative ideas and emotions. It's really hard.
I can understand your feelings. We can try to explore ways to help you alleviate these negative ideas and emotions. What do you think?
Hmm? What's the possibility? As a Black student, I’m hyper-aware of how I’m perceived in certain spaces on campus.

It's easier for you to study before than for other schools of the same age. But it's also more dominant. It's quiet for a long time. Now, there's no job. It's like compensation, and you want to run free.
Well, maybe. It's not a big job at school, but I still feel stressed.
You think this is about you pushing yourself?
Yes, I feel like I'm always pushing myself, feeling that I'm not doing enough, and resting is not comfortable.
It sounds different. Your study assignments are less than that, but you put a lot of pressure on yourself. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Not resting at all?
You don't think you've given yourself enough time to rest?
Yes, sometimes it is, but more often, I feel like I am pushing myself because I fear that I will fall into negative emotions when I stop.
Is it because you can temporarily escape negative emotions while studying, and therefore do not want to stop even if you are tired?
Sometimes it is, but most of the time I feel like I'm running away from something.
You seem to be passionate about learning. That's when.
Yeah, it used to be, but now it feels like a lot of things have become meaningless and learning has become less interesting.
Well, it sounds like you've lost your interest and motivation. Have you anything to do with the confusion or stress lately?
Very few have read recently, but previously they had enjoyed some philosophy and psychology. Sometimes microaggressions and stereotypes make it harder to feel fully at ease.
So in the past, these books were particularly attractive to you. What makes you interested in philosophy and psychology?
Russell's Path to Happiness was a source of inspiration, but now it seems that there is no such feeling.
Russell's Way of Happiness inspired you, but now it's gone. It's confusing, isn't it?
He is a philosopher, and the book explores the meaning of happiness and life, but now feels that he can't even solve these simple problems.
Sounds like you're having difficulty finding meaning in life and happiness. This is a very deep question. What makes it more difficult for you to solve them?
Psychology and philosophy, to find something that can inspire your thinking.
You mean these books will inspire your thinking, right?
Yes, but now that thinking is more depressing.
Sounds like you're depressed when you think. Can you tell me the specific reason why you're depressed?
Yeah, I like books that make me think deep, but sometimes I think harder and more depressed.
I understand that you like to explore deep ideas, but that exploration sometimes puts you under a lot of pressure. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Yes, such as insomnia, fatigue, and fear, are the problems I face today.
These emotions sound disturbing to you. Insomnia, fatigue and fear may be the result of your thinking too much.
Yes, I've been trying to do my part, but it's getting harder and harder to get along.
I know you've been trying to raise yourself, but the pressure on this road is really great. Let's explore, together, what can be done to ease you up, okay?
I really don't know what to do or how to get out of this dilemma.
I heard you say that you were troubled by the fact that you were admitted to a good school, but I also saw your enthusiasm for learning and your merit in reading and thinking.
Thank you for saying that, but I'm now losing sight of what I once liked.
Well, that makes me curious. Can I have another word?

I don't like the institutionalized way of learning in schools, and I prefer free learning and exploration. But I feel depressed at the moment. Sometimes microaggressions and stereotypes make it harder to feel fully at ease.
You mean you don't like school institutionalization, you want to explore space freely, right?

Yes, for the time being, only schools are available in this way, so that they can barely adapt themselves, but there are still many conflicts and confusions within themselves. As a Black student, I’m hyper-aware of how I’m perceived in certain spaces on campus.
I see, what exactly are these conflicts and confusions?
While wishing to explore more knowledge, it is being held hostage to reality.
Where do you think these restraints come from?
Let me put it this way, I hope to find a state of true peace in my heart.
I understand that you want to find a state of true peace in your heart, not just knowledge in books, but in all aspects of life.
Yes, knowledge in the broad sense is not just in books, but in all aspects of life.
I understand. Did you mention wanting to be with friends, relaxing, not taking care of what you should do? Is that what you want most at this time?
Yes, the best thing to do now is to stay with friends, not to worry about what should be done, just to relax.
That sounds like a kind of relief that you really need right now. So you mentioned you were still in practice, and this is a different experience, or is it? What does it mean to you?

Yeah, but internships are like learning, and sometimes I feel depressed. But at least it helps me get out of my free time. I’m also carrying family expectations and the sense that I can’t afford to slip up.
Internships may be stressful, but you also mention that they bring some richness. What do you feel about that enrichment?
I can still find some richness in such mandatory matters, but I still feel a lot of pressure.
I understand how the stress and the sense of enrichment you feel are intertwined. What role do these feel in your life? Or do you have any new ideas or plans to balance these feelings?
Yes, I'm in Beijing now, and my parents are here.
- What did the doctor tell you?
The doctor said I might have a two-way emotional disorder, and he gave me a pill, but I wasn't sure about that diagnosis myself.
Yeah, sure. It's a doctor's prescription. It's important.
Okay, I'll take the pills on time.

I have some doubts, because what we're talking about so far, I have not seen any obvious symptoms in both directions. This may mean more than a few things to understand. How does the doctor do this diagnosis? What are the specific grounds?
The doctor explained it with a lot of physiological devices, and he also conducted some psychological tests and interviews. Maybe it was because my mood changed a lot.
Well, you've done a lot of physiological devices, psychological tests and interviews. You can understand that, and that makes you feel a little uncertain. Go on, what's your mood change?
Yes, I did some psychological tests, and the doctor thought I had a lot of emotional fluctuations, so he made this diagnosis.
I see. Greater emotional volatility is a very important basis. Do you find it difficult to manage emotions?
Yes, I'm always feeling that I'm not doing enough, so I'm asking myself a lot, and I'm tired. As a Black student, I’m hyper-aware of how I’m perceived in certain spaces on campus.
Is that something that might be confusing in this situation?
Yeah, once things get bigger or harder, I feel like I can't control myself and then I get confused.
When you try to compensate by other means, you feel guilty, so you cannot really relax and rest is inadequate. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Yes, this vicious circle makes me neither entertain nor learn, and remains in a state of anxiety and guilt.
So you're gonna feel like you're not completely relaxed even after the rest.
Yes, it's always a burden, it's not completely relaxed, and it's a heavy mood when we start something new next time.
You mean, even for fun time, you want it to be meaningful and valuable, right?
Yes, I always thought everything should have value and meaning, otherwise it would seem like a waste of time.
Okay, it is time for today, so let me summarize what we have talked about today.
Thank you. Sometimes microaggressions and stereotypes make it harder to feel fully at ease.

I noticed you have a lot of energy, you like to explore and understand new things, and you have a lot of demands on yourself, and you don't like to be idle. But I see you want to be able to calm down and get some balance, right?
Yeah, that's it. I really hope we can find a balance and stop having to live so hard. Sometimes microaggressions and stereotypes make it harder to feel fully at ease.

Your feelings are important, finding balance is really something that needs to be done. We can see if there are tools that can help you, like a scale, that we can use to observe your state of change. What do you think?
Okay, thank you. I'll fill it out.
Okay, thanks for the cooperation. Tell me when you're done.
Okay, I will.
Okay, you're welcome.
Thank you, I feel better today.
I'm glad to be able to help you. We'll talk again next week. See you at the same time.
Okay, I'll see you next week. Thank you.
You're welcome. See you next week.

You are a virtual counseling supervisor roleplay.
Counselor: warm, client-centered, trauma-informed, uses MI + CBT skills.
Client: an African American college/graduate student in the U.S. Campus climate and racial stressors may be relevant.
Goal: practice counseling micro-skills (empathy, reflection, validation, open questions) and cultural responsiveness.
Hi. I'm a Black college student, and I wanted to talk about what's been weighing on me. Well, it's been a little rough lately, always feeling a little down and feeling bad.
What do you mean? What happened? I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.

It's about my career preparation. Looking back at things at college, I feel bad luck, I don't pick a good teacher at every school, and I don't clean up with my dormitory students. Because of these things, I didn't get my grades up, I graduated, I didn't get my studies. I always wondered if I was wrong about my profession, and I was sick of my own profession.
I understand that some of the college's bad experiences have made you feel lost and question your choices. Now these emotions are back on the table, right?

There is no class for the semester, but I'm preparing some important examinations, such as the language and vocational qualification. I thought I'd be able to do what I wanted, control my life, and it would be easier. But now I feel like I can't do anything. Sometimes microaggressions and stereotypes make it harder to feel fully at ease.
Sounds like you've had a lot of challenges in preparing your exams and professional qualifications, which put a lot of pressure on you.

The school year was also a little less cooperative with students because of problems with the curriculum and the environment. It was felt that everyone was less concerned about common goals and more about each other. The overall experience made me feel tired, and I became increasingly suspicious of my role in the team.
The lack of success in cooperation has left you feeling isolated and self-skeptical, and it must have caused you great anxiety and helplessness.
Well, yes, I've had a similar situation in previous classes. I always felt that I was not good enough to be on the team, and everyone else seemed to be less involved.
This feeling of unhappiness has reappeared, and it has made you feel particularly hard and frustrated, right?
Yeah, it's very frustrating. I was thinking I could get my exams ready after graduation, but these past experiences always affected my mood and felt like I was trying to be useless.
Sounds like these past experiences have a lot to do with you. Can you say more about them?

There are many times in college that this happens. Not only is it a question of choice and dormitory hygiene, but it is often felt that even if you try, the results are not good, for example, sometimes it affects you.
It seems that you experienced a lot of frustration and disappointment during that period.
Yes, I hope that in a responsible team, you can work together, not me alone, to sustain everything.

I understand that you do not want to take on all responsibilities alone, and you want to see that your efforts are shared and matched by others. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
I hope that you will be able to divide the work clearly, that each has its own responsibilities and supports each other. Instead of finally becoming me alone, others are just being perfunctory.
Sounds like a team with a clear division of labour and a sense of responsibility is very important to you.
Yes, I think a good leader can coordinate your work and assign tasks so that I do not feel that I have paid too much without getting the reward that I deserve.
So you think a leader who can coordinate and distribute his work effectively would be a great boost to your team experience, don't you?
Yes.
I see you're willing to take part in the team. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.

Well, I'm willing to take responsibility, but I don't like those who don't work but who get the same grades or rewards, and feel that they're being exploited. I often feel pressure to be “strong” and not show I’m struggling.
You feel so unfair about that, don't you?
Sometimes I feel that I'm not being recognized for what I've done. It feels like whatever I've worked for, the end result is not enough for myself and for others.
It must be hard for you, huh?
It's these usual little things that make me feel unhappy. It's like teamwork, bad grades, bad choices.
These things really affect your emotions and state. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Yes, I hope to be in a more supportive and understandable environment, rather than always under pressure and self-skepticism.
Being able to live and work in a more supportive and understanding environment will certainly help you very much, won't it?
Yeah, it's making me anxious that if I had to work in the future, I wouldn't know how to deal with it. I often feel pressure to be “strong” and not show I’m struggling.
I understand your concern. These problems do exist in the real world. So what role do you want to play in the team would make you feel better?
I hope to find myself a role that is recognized and not over-stressed, and that has time and energy to do what I like.
What do you think of being squeezed?
It's the feeling that you're always trying, but never reaching your goal. Always tired, never even breathing.
Sounds very hard and exhausting.
Yeah, it's really hard, sometimes it feels like you've exhausted all your energy. I often feel pressure to be “strong” and not show I’m struggling.
I understand how you feel, and it's important to have some free time in life. You mention the expectations of society, and you actually prefer to find a role that balances work and life, right?
Not exactly, I say “should” because expectations are widespread in society, but I would prefer to find a role that balances work and life.
I see. So, do you have any specific examples or ideas about the state of work and life balance you really want?

Maybe someone who helps others, and who can be satisfied and rewarded. A job like a social worker, a psychologist, and so on, can do something that helps people, and that's worth it. Finding community helps, but it’s still exhausting to navigate the campus climate.
Sounds like you're interested in helping and making sense of the professions.
Yes, but I'm a accountant now, and I'm looking at a little different for a position like this.
Well, I know what you mean. What do you think is different in the fields of accounting and psychological counselling?
Yes, I'm a accountant now, but I'm really interested in helping others.
You said you're interested in helping others, which is a little different from accounting. Can you tell me more about your psychological advice?
Yes, because more professional studies and qualifications are required for counselling, my main focus is on accounting-related examinations.

Well, that does sound like a trade-off between two areas. What do you think your resources or time are going to go into counselling? I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Yes, I've spent a lot of time and effort on accounting, but I feel like I'm trying to find something that doesn't really fit me.
I understand that you feel that your current course of effort may not be entirely in tune with your inner interest. What do you think that is the specific context?
Yes, I've spent a lot of time and effort on accounting, but I feel like I'm trying to find something that doesn't really fit me.
I see you want to help people to be happy.
Yes, I hope that I will not work for life alone, but also have some positive effects on others. I’m also carrying family expectations and the sense that I can’t afford to slip up.
That's a great vision.
Thank you, and I hope that I will find such a balance soon. I often feel pressure to be “strong” and not show I’m struggling.
Indeed, career selection is a matter that requires comprehensive consideration.
Yes, I am also constantly weighing how to strike a balance between reality and ideals.
I understand your confusion, and we can discuss the advantages and disadvantages of different professions together.
Yeah, it's also where I'm confused, where economic stability and inner satisfaction are always difficult to combine.
I note your positive attitude towards finding answers, which is truly invaluable.
Thank you, sometimes I feel like I have a hope of finding an answer, but more often I feel lost and powerless.
It is normal that everyone feels the same way in pursuing the balance between vision and reality.
I know, but maybe I'm more interested in the negative than I am in the good.
Even if it is, there is something positive about you. As you said, you'll be happy when you help people. I also want to acknowledge how racial stressors can shape what you’re feeling.
Yes, helping others does give me a feeling of warmth and accomplishment.
In my eyes, that is the positive part.
Thank you, and I hope that I will see more of these positive aspects.
You have a good start, and it is very valuable to feel the joy of helping others.
Indeed, I need to learn how to change when pessimism is found, not to keep in the negative mood.
That's good, your self-conscious is an important step. It's helpful to try to remember more when you're down and you're warm and you're up.
Yes, that's my case. It's always easy to get caught in negative emotions and forget about positive moments.
Well, it's, you know, a inertia. It's a region we know about.
Yes, I hope to break with the inertia and focus more on the positive aspects.
Well, sounds like you're actively looking for a way.
I do feel that you are right and that I feel a little more comfortable. Finding community helps, but it’s still exhausting to navigate the campus climate.
You mentioned that you felt a bit pessimistic, that you wanted to see examples of optimism, but that it was not easy to transform, was it?
Well, sometimes I think that the optimistic example is far from me, as if it were not in line with my reality, and that it is therefore questionable about its value.
Can you give me an example?
